data.title: VSCode 1.15.1 Output default coding is not utf-8
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.15.1
- OS Version:MacOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I use Code-Runner plugin or Python plugin to run python codes

2. if I print some Chinese Char(encoded in utf-8)  in output window, it show below error:
UnicodeEncodeError: 'charmap' codec can't encode character
This is caused by the output window's default coding is not utf-8 but ascii. 

Please also refer to this issue: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44724461/task-output-encoding-in-vscode

Sublime Text3 and Atom don't have this issue on Mac.

I changed python cmd as below for a workround:
 "python": "export PYTHONIOENCODING=utf-8 && cd $dir && python $fileName",

please fix this bug .
Thanks.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Implement extension host restarting
data.body:
When the extension host crashes, the only way to recover is by reloading the window.

Implement a mechanism to correctly clean up state in the workbench due to the extension host and add an action to restart the extension host.

data.title: When encountering errors, identify the extension they came from
data.body: It's beneficial to know what extension threw what (caught/uncaught) error.

data.title: Uninstall telemetry
data.body: The Marketplace would like to offer extension authors more telemetry data. One of those data points is the number of uninstalls.

data.title: support magic comments for specifying file encoding

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Some programming languages use magic comments at the beginning of a file to specify the encoding of that file. From what I can see, this is not supported by vscode. I would like to suggest to have it implemented. It is a problem when one has projects where there are multiple encodings used across the code base.

data.title: Allow critical extensions to run on the main thread

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
From the Code documentation:

> All extensions when activated run in our shared extension host process. This separate process for extensions ensures that VS Code remains responsive through-out.

I think that, in general, is a great approach as responsiveness is _very_ important. However, I would argue that the current model could be even better. Currently, it does not account for some use cases. In these cases serious responsiveness problems can still be encountered.

I use Code together with [VSCodeVim](https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim). Recently I was having a problem with one of the extensions I've installed. The extension was misbehaving and using a lot of CPU. Since both VSCodeVim and the misbehaving extension was running on the same thread editing was made completely impossible.

Extensions like VSCodeVim becomes their user's primary way of interacting with their editor. If the VSCodeVim extension is unresponsive due to another extension then the whole editing experience is unresponsive.

I would argue that key extensions like VSCodeVim should be allowed to run on the main thread or a thread separate from the other extensions. Otherwise using extensions like VSCodeVim will always result in a less responsive and less stable editing experience.

data.title: Can't make word pattern works with double ticks (for renaming)
data.body:
In F#, we are allowed to name a variable like ` ``test`` ` (the double ticks are not an error)

In order to match this kind of variable and allowing renaming them, I created this regex:

```
(``((\w*\s?)\s?)*``)|((\w*')(\w'?)*)|(-?\d*\.\d\w*)|([^\`\~\!\@\$\^\&\*\(\)\=\+\[\{\]\}\\\|\;\:\'\"\,\.\<\>\/\s]+)
```

As you can see [here](https://regex101.com/r/laVr9h/1) it's matching the variables names as expected. However, when trying to rename it by pressing F2 in VSCode it's only capture `test`

-----------

- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Windows Pro x64, Linux Mint 18.2

-----------

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set the regex into wordPattern for a plugin.
2. Write this line: `let ``test`` = "" `
3. Try to rename ` ``test`` ` into `newName`

Same test for: ` ``test multiple words`` `

Here is a gif to demonstrate the issue:

![vscode_double_tick](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4760796/29449681-f745cf58-83fb-11e7-935a-fd93b3a95379.gif)

data.title: workspace search: error parsing glob, nested alternate groups are not allowed
data.body:
### Setup

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
java-properties|ith|0.0.2
vscode-jsp|pth|0.0.2
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
perforce|sle|2.1.1

(1 theme extensions excluded)

### Steps to Reproduce

with VSCode opened in folder `C:/MyFolder`

1. open workspace search (via `[CTRL][SHIFT][F]` or the magnifier icon in the activity bar)
2. specify a glob for *files to include*, e.g. `**/{MyFile1,MyFile2}.js`
3. search for anything

#### Expected:
search results only for files matching the glob

#### Actual: 
"search" field marked as invalid, shows the following error on focus:

> error parsing glob `'MyFolder\{**\{MyFile1,MyFile2}.js\**,**\{MyFile1,MyFile2}.js}'`: nested alternate groups are not allowed

Reproduces without extensions: Yes (started `code --disable-extensions`, reproduced the issue)

data.title: Extension readme with markdown table generates inline styles CSP warnings
data.body:
From https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/issues/1703 **Repo** Open an extension page in the extension explorer for an extension whose readme uses a table. The c# extension is a good example: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/master/README.md **Bug** CSP warning about: `Refused to apply Inline style` The root cause is that markdown tables generate html with inline styles: ```
Master Release
```

data.title: editor.tokenColorCustomizations.textMateRules.settings.background not applied
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 x86
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add to settings
```
 "editor.tokenColorCustomizations":
    {
        "textMateRules":[        
            {
                
                "name": "Invalid",                
                "scope": "invalid",
                "settings": {
                    "background": "#FF0000",
                    "foreground": "#FFFFFF"
                }
            }
        ],
        "strings": "#3ad900"        
    },    
```
2. ```foreground``` color #FFFFFF is applied, but ```background``` color #FF0000 is not, it remains as it is (#800F00)
3.  Using ```Generate color theme from current settings``` shows 2 sets of ```"Invalid"```
4.
```
		{
			"name": "Invalid",
			"scope": "invalid",
			"settings": {
				"background": "#800F00",
				"foreground": "#F8F8F8"
			}
		},
...
		{
			"name": "Invalid",
			"scope": "invalid",
			"settings": {
				"background": "#FF0000",
				"foreground": "#FFFFFF"
			}
		}
```
5. I'm expecting either set 1 or set 2 to be used, however, background is from set 1, foreground is from set 2.
6. Looks like a bug to me, or is it by design?

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: User Settings - Sort the settings upon save

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
For example my current settings looks something like this.
```json
  "workbench.colorTheme": "Snazzy Operator",
  "editor.fontSize": 14,
  "editor.multiCursorModifier": "ctrlCmd",
  "editor.wordWrap": "on",
  "window.zoomLevel": 0,
  "editor.lineHeight": 28,
  "newFile.relativeTo": "file",
  "tslint.autoFixOnSave": true,
  "workbench.iconTheme": "material-icon-theme",
  "sync.lastUpload": "2017-08-10T18:09:58.276Z",
  "sync.autoDownload": false,
  "sync.autoUpload": false,
  "sync.lastDownload": "",
  "sync.forceDownload": false,
  "sync.anonymousGist": false,
  "sync.host": "",
  "sync.pathPrefix": "",
  "sync.quietSync": false,
  "sync.askGistName": false,
  "prettier.singleQuote": true,
  "workbench.statusBar.visible": true,
  "editor.fontLigatures": true
```

It would be great if on saving the settings, it automatically sorted it so all related settings appear to be at one place.

```json

data.title: Rename input widget should use text editor widget
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: June 2017 (version 1.14)
- OS Version: Mac OS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Given code;
```
import URLS from '..';

const contactUs = (
  <Link href={URLS.MY_WEBSITE}>
    contact us
  </Link>);
```
2. select variable name in import `URL`
3. press `F2` in order to rename variable
4. press shortcut to transform to lowercase (it must use shortcut to reproduce). In my case `OPT + CMD + L`
5. expected import line and code line to be transformed to lowercase.
6. result: only import is in lowercase

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Thank you 
Leonardo Correa

data.title: open existing tab if available, with split editors (single instanced files across splits)
data.body:
If there are split editors, then opening a file will open a copy in the split which has focus, even if that file is already open in another split. Feature request: an option such that if a file is open in any split, re-opening that file will navigate to the existing opened editor.

My use case is that I have one central file open in my first split, and many files open in a second split, and I navigate very frequently between different files while leaving my central file open. But opening a file creates a copy in whichever split has focus, so trying to click on a file obscures my central file with 50-50 chance unless I manually focus the second split beforehand.

This feature request allows me to pre-open all the files in my second split, so that opening any file will view it in the second split, leaving my central file open. An alternative solution would be a (configurable) "main" split in which all new files are opened, which would solve my use case directly without needing to pre-open files, but that opens up some UI issues since one of the splits is now special.

data.title: Disabling auto-indent doesn't actually disable auto-indent
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disable editor.autoIndent.
![Auto Indent Disabled Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1544943/29439725-8aa51750-8374-11e7-835d-938c697db3ed.png)

2. Create a new file with this content and save it with a .cpp extension:
```
template<class _FwdIt,
	class _Ty,
	class _Fn>
	_Ty _Reduce_unchecked(_Parallel_policy_tag, _FwdIt _First, _FwdIt _Last, _Ty _Val, _Fn _Reduction)
	{	// return reduction, parallelized
	const size_t _Hw_threads = __std_parallel_algorithms_hw_threads();
	size_t _Count;
	if (_Hw_threads <= 1)
		{
		goto serial;
		}
	|| (_Count = _STD distance(_First, _Last)) < 2)
		{	// don't parallelize on uniprocessor machines or less than 2 elements
		return (_Reduce_unchecked(_First, _Last, _STD move(_Val), _Reduction));
		}
	}
```

3. Position the cursor on the line after "goto serial;" at the end. Press enter.
![Bug Demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1544943/29439748-b7accf18-8374-11e7-9d6f-3bee279c0c85.png)

4. VS code moved that closing curly brace back 1 indent instead of leaving it alone.
![Bug Reprod](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1544943/29439757-cd0e3ee6-8374-11e7-9a8b-314e751735d4.png)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: [themes] Incorrect syntax highlighting after destructured function arguments with a default value in JS
Roblou/fixsmoketest1
Opening folder the contains node_modules folder takes more CPU memory than opening a sub-folder that doesn't
data.body:
I tested this with 2 different laptops. Looks like opening a folder in VSCode that contains node_modules folder makes Vs Code consume more CPU memory (12% more). Opening a sub folder is better but then i can't access angular-cli.json from VsCode folder explorer. Can someone please verify and look into it? Thanks
